segments.text: It was a late morning when suddenly the phone rang.
She went over, picked up the receiver and said, hello.
For a moment there was silence on the other end of the line.
Then suddenly she heard, hello.
That deep and so familiar voice, which she hadn't heard since her release.
It was the battalion commander.
Very excited, she responded with a tone mixed with reverence.
Hello, the battalion commander, how are you?
It's good to hear you.
On the other end of the line, the battalion commander was thrilled that she immediately recognized his voice.
So much time had passed, he thought, and he had no idea what was happening with her.
Suddenly, he felt the urge to check how she was doing, knowing that contrary to what everyone thought, Dan had yet to return.
Unbelievable that you recognized my voice.
He said, I'm sorry I haven't spoken to you for so long.
I should have.
Somehow the intense days here sometimes push aside the truly important things.
I often thought of you worried.
Why, she said, embarrassed.
You didn't have to, and I'm just fine.
Maybe except for the longing and uncertainty that sometimes gnaw at me.
Tell me.
Don't you come to Ashkelon sometimes?
I'd be thrilled if you visited.
And I also have a little surprise to show you.
Strange you mention it.
I'm in the Castina area.
Need to take care of some things here.
I guess I'll finish in about two hours and we'll happily drop by.
Can you tell me your address?
She laughed.
I don't really have an address.
I live in the pink house.
That's what it's called.
And that's also its address.
Anyone you ask will know how to direct you.
Is it really pink?"
he asked, puzzled.
Yes, it's really pink and even has red shutters.
Now he laughed too.
Something eased in their tentative conversation, how glad he was that she invited him.
She sounded so direct and even more mature than she already was from what he remembered.
I'll come," he said.
Great, have lunch with us, she replied.
Only after hanging up the phone did he realize that she said with us and remembered that she had a father.
When she heard his jeep stop at the entrance, she went out to meet him with a big smile on her face.
God, he thought, she looks like a girl, thin and tall, in pants and a simple tank top, her feet bare.
Yet her eyes so mature.
What a contrast between what was inside them and her appearance.
They stood smiling at each other.
She thought to herself that he had added a few worry lines and that his hair had whitened a bit more, but otherwise he remained the same.
She gave him a warm look and after a slight hesitation went up and hugged him.
He laughed, surprised.
I'm so happy to see you.
It's great you came.
They walked inside together.
Is this a hotel?
You live in a hotel?
He was amazed.
Yes, she laughed, in such a hotel, a pink hotel.
He looked around at the beautiful and well-kept place, his eyes resting on the tables with wooden chairs, the tablecloths, and small flower vases.
And through the glass doors he saw the large garden outside.
Then he noticed the beautiful paintings on the walls.
What beautiful pictures, he said.
Those are paintings by my father, she said, with not a little pride.

You can understand why a painter who came to live in white houses on a white sand dune feels the need to add some color to the surroundings and paints everything in pink and the shutters in red, and only then writes in round, beautiful letters on the sign at the entrance, the pink house.
I didn't know your house was a hotel, he said.
She looked at him with a shy smile.
You didn't know a lot of things, she said quietly, for a moment she was silent.

Then continued and said, for example, you didn't know that I've been running this hotel alone for almost two years, back from the time I was in the army, and you didn't know that I used to drive Dan's military jeep without a license after he gave me a ride and fell asleep at the wheel.
For a moment she was silent again.
Her gaze turned misty.
Then she added in a slightly hoarse voice.
That's how it actually started between us.
After a contemplative pause, she continued.
And the most you didn't know, she said while looking at him intently, and then turned her gaze to the garden and suddenly called out loudly.
Ben, Ben, where are you?
And suddenly he saw in the flower bed a little baby, not yet a year old, standing and clapping his hands.
Come, sweetie, come say hello to the battalion commander.
The battalion commander froze in place, looking in amazement at little Dan, toddling towards them with a big smile on his face.
His dark curls danced to the rhythm of his steps, and only when he was really close did he notice his so blue eyes, his mother's eyes.
He was speechless, not knowing what to say.
He looked at the girl in front of him, at the so mature person she was, and with a simple calculation, understood that she was already in advanced pregnancy when she finished her service.
God!"
his voice rasped.
How didn't you say anything?
How did you manage to deal with all this alone?
Somehow, she said quietly, this child is the most wonderful thing that happened to me.
As if Dan knew I'd have to wait for him alone, and arranged for me a companion to fill my days and heart, assuring himself that I wouldn't forget how he looks.
He's a wonderful child, and it's not really hard for me.
I just so wish he would already meet his amazing father."
Then Ben heard the word father, smiled a big smile, and said, F-A-F-C-Dan.
The three of them laughed, and a little later, he already waddled to the mat in the kitchen lobby, laid down his head, and fell asleep.
They talked for hours.
She told him she sees Dan in her dreams, that they communicate somehow, that she's sure he's in a Spanish-speaking country and has a strong feeling it'll soon be over.
Two weeks ago, she dreamed he was sick.
Then she saw him again sitting in his cafe with the beret and the beard he grew, just a bit paler.
But today she woke up early in the morning when it was still completely dark with a heavy sense of worry, almost anxiety.
Even the sparrows in the garden chirped cries.
Only Ben-Ben managed to calm her soul.
I also write to him from the day he disappeared, she told the battalion commander, so he'd know everything he missed and all that's in my heart.
When she got up from their sitting place to make them black coffee, he asked her permission to use the phone.
He walked a few steps to the reception desk and after a minute she heard him talking quietly but with a bit of firmness.
For a moment he raised his voice and it seemed to her that he said, It can't be, you have to do something.
For a moment she didn't hear anything as apparently the person on the other side of the device spoke to him.
Then the battalion commander responded quietly.
Okay, I'll wait for you here.
No, there's no address.
Just ask where the pink house is.
Any child will know how to tell you.
So strange, she thought to herself.
She never heard him raise his voice.
Something or someone probably really annoyed him.
From the conversation, she understood he would stay with her for a while longer, waiting for that mysterious person on the other end.
Maybe take the coffee and move to lounge on one of the garden chairs?
She suggested to the battalion commander.
I understand you're waiting for someone.
That way, you can relax a bit, and in the meantime, I'll finish a few things I need to do.
The battalion commander lounged on the garden chair and took a long sip from his coffee cup.
How pleasant it is here, he thought.
The place is surrounded by a high hedge, as if enclosing the garden and hiding it from the outside.
Only the beautiful sign with the round letters hangs high under the street lamp, visible even above the hedge.
It's such a special house, but he didn't understand where her father was.
He remembered she said long ago that her mother had passed away a few years before her enlistment.
But then she also added, it's just my father and me.
And that's OK.
Now he realized that actually it's just her.
She was there all along.

what courage he thought to himself and in addition there's something so calm in her conduct as if she knows exactly what she needs to do and does it with complete professional skill the house is well kept and clean and from the moment you enter it it envelops you in such a warm and special atmosphere
He closed his eyes for a moment, seeing Dan before them, and immediately, Little Benben's image came up in front of him, resembling him so much.
Earlier, she told him she was already in her seventh month when she was released from the army.
He recalled how towards the end of her service, he thought to himself that she added a kilo to her weight and how it suited her.
but it was winter and she was in her big sweater over her loose pants.
Nothing was noticeable.
Just nothing.
He hoped that she managed to support herself from the few rooms she rented.
The meal they ate together didn't shame any good homemade food restaurant.
She's just a young girl and what she's already been through.
He apparently dozed off for a while.
His eyes opened when he felt Benven's little hand clutching his leg, trying to climb on him.
In his other hand, he held a book with colorful pictures.
My garden, he said.
He helped him climb onto his knees and hugged him with a smile.
Come, sweetie, do you want me to read you a story?
Ten.
Ben then said and nodded.
how cute this child is, and how much he resembles Dan, as if someone molded his pattern in small, and only his so blue eyes remind that he also has a mother.
For a moment, the battalion commander felt a lump in his throat.
He hoped with all his heart that Dan was okay, and more than anything hoped he'd return soon to all the goodness waiting for him.
Lyora peeked from the kitchen window.
Her heart warm in front of this picture of the battalion commander, with Ben Ben on his lap, and him reading him a story.
From time to time, Ben repeated the ends of words and clapped for himself, and the battalion commander said, good job.
This is a friend of dad's, she thought to herself, and also a bit of mom's.
Surprisingly, despite the distance in their status and age as battalion commander and junior officer, there was always warmth and mutual respect between them.
It wasn't said in words, but it was palpable.
She always thought that contrary to what you'd expect from a commander of an elite unit, he had humility and human warmth.
Before being a commander, he's a mensch.
It always made her feel comfortable around him, even in the most serious discussions.
There was great joy in her about his visit, and the fact that she could pour her heart out to him and reveal her big secret to him.
Interesting what happened that he felt the need to contact her suddenly.
Here, despite the early morning's alarming feelings, which warned, she had a wonderful and joyful day.
Only deep in her heart did she know that there was something about that sharp intuition she felt that shouldn't be ignored.
But at this moment, preferred to push it aside.
Now is good.
Hours passed, and no one came.
You see, said the battalion commander.
I'm waiting for someone.
But if he doesn't arrive within the next hour, I'll simply go.
I have to get home this evening.
I promised my wife I'd join her at our oldest daughter's party.
It doesn't always work out, and when it does, it's sacred.
Fair enough, she replied.
Today I understand that when you have children, they come much before you.
They're everything.
I'm not sure I always had a good example of this.
But sometimes I think that precisely because of this, I'm two-thirds responsibility and only the rest a little water.
She smiled a contemplative smile, thinking of her special dad who sometimes forgot to be a dad.
What a wonderful definition, said the battalion commander.
A short while later, he parted from her, not before promising to return soon to visit Ben-Ben.
This time he was the one who hugged her, feeling a warm and free paternal emotion towards her.
Knowing that his soul was bound to Dan's and her little sons, towards ten at night she finished gathering everything and setting the tables for the next morning.
To her surprise, everyone quickly went to their rooms after dinner and around it.
It was completely quiet.
She read in the armchair in the corner for a while, only the lamp above her on and some of the garden lamps also lighting inward.

and she was already about to take the few steps to gather up Ben-Ben from the mat, when suddenly there was a knock on the door, and after a slight hesitation and without waiting for an answer, it opened.
A tall slender man stood before her.
He wore glasses and his straight hair was neatly combed with a side parting.
I didn't know if I needed to knock on the door or just come in," he told her.
I'm several hours late and guess I missed the battalion commander.
Something came up suddenly and I couldn't arrive on time, but I decided to come nonetheless despite the late hour.
It's good you're still up.
My name is Gideon.
Nice to meet you.
He extended his hand for a shake and only then realized she had no idea who he was or what he was doing there.
Sorry, I didn't mean to scare you.
I'm not easily scared, but I admit that not every day does the door open here at such a late hour.
It's usually the time when everyone goes to sleep.
Can we sit somewhere?
He asked.
Yes, sure.
She replied and moved a chair close to the armchair.
They sat facing each other.
He leaned towards her.
And from the work of Dan, he stated a fact, leaving her open mouthed.
She began to understand that the battalion commander had called there.
But what did he want?
My father also worked in that work years ago.
Isser even attended my first birthday in the snow on Tel Aviv.
She said with a half smile, trying to reassure him she was in the know, even though she really wasn't.
She had no idea about anything and didn't have the faintest clue what this Gideon wanted from her.
She was a bit stressed from the whole situation.
Sitting there with the unknown man from Dan's work close to midnight in this almost dark house,
with her little son sleeping a few meters from them.
Look, I don't know where to begin, but mainly I owe you an apology.
We had no clue of your existence, and certainly had no idea there was also a baby in this story.
If we had known, we would have reached out to you long ago.
Truth is, we're not in the right here.
My check today, after getting a scolding from the battalion commander, revealed to me that Dan mentioned you as his first contact to be reached in case of need.
No one gave it a second thought because we know his family and had no idea he had a partner.
From our perspective, it doesn't matter if you're his wife or not.
You're his partner in every sense.
And basically, you and your little boy, you're his family.
All this time, she hadn't uttered a word.
When he said you're his partner, her heart fluttered.
And when he said you're his family, she already felt the lump climbing in her throat.
Knowing that in another moment, tears would well up in her eyes.
Here she received confirmation of Dan's love for her when he listed her as his first contact.
But a moment later, that fleeting happiness passed and she was gripped with anxiety again.
Maybe something happened to him and he wants to tell her.
Maybe he really was sick or something worse.
Maybe her intuition and the crying sparrows from the morning were right.
She lifted her gaze to him.
Is he all right?
She asked in a trembling voice.
As far as I know, he's fine.
I don't know too much.
I'm from a different department.
But I assume if he weren't fine, I would have already known.
That's not why I'm here.
He tried to reassure her.
Look, he explained, you're entitled to a monthly allowance for the entire period that Dan wasn't here with you and is still absent.
I'll make sure you receive it retroactively from the day of his departure.
Unbelievable, but it's over a year.
I need you to give me your bank account details so I can enter them into the system.
I'm really sorry for all the confusion.
I hope Dan doesn't kill me when he comes back.
I don't understand how you're managing.
I understand this is a small hotel.
You work here?
Who owns it?
What do you live on?
She looked at him in amazement, almost defiantly.
This is my hotel, she exclaimed, and after a second added, for now.
I'm running it alone ever since my military service.
It's small and limited, but you don't have to worry about me.
I'm managing somehow.
But I admit that the idea of receiving a supplement to my small monthly income is quite reassuring.
It wouldn't have crossed my mind that there's such a thing.
On second thought, maybe I'll decide to save it until Dan returns.
Only if I'm really in need will I touch it.
Let him decide what to do with this money, since he has no idea he has a son.
Come, see," she said suddenly, feeling a bit more confident now.
He got up from his chair, walked behind her towards the mat, and stood in his place as he saw this miracle that looked exactly, exactly like Dan.
His curls were spread around his head, but since his eyes were closed, Gideon couldn't know they were as blue as his mother's.
He's simply charming, he said, his voice also rasping a bit.

Even this service man, who knew how to hide all his emotions from his surroundings, couldn't overcome the emotion that overwhelmed him, watching the sweet baby, whose father knew nothing about his existence.
I'm leaving you a phone number.
You can call for any issue that arises for you.
And if there's anything else you need, just tell me, I'd be very happy to help.
Tell me, he added and suddenly asked, do you have a driver's license?
No, she replied, but I also don't have a car.
So it doesn't matter.
I actually know how to drive very well, but I don't have a license.
And to be honest in Aphrodare, you don't really need a car.
And if you need to go shopping or something, the bus stop is right outside the house.
Why do you ask?
just wanted to know.
She felt he was dodging but was too tired to probe further.
He parted from her with a warm handshake.
Everything will be okay, he assured her.
She locked the door behind him, a bit confused by everything that had happened.
In her heart, she thought he looked more like a bank clerk than one of Dan's work.
Something calmed within her knowing they now knew of her existence.
Before he left, she asked that if they had any contact with Dan, they should under no circumstances tell him about Ben Ben.
It's she who wants to tell him and introduce them for the first time.
She couldn't fall asleep, swept again by that strange worry, and a great longing enveloped her.
She spoke to Dan in her heart.
Please just come back already.
It's so much already.
I don't need any Gideons or any allowances.
I just want you back.
Please.
I'm not as brave as Noga says.
I just want to lay my head in the nook of your neck and smell the dust in your hair.
I want us to walk barefoot, the three of us, Dad, Mom and Ben-Ben, on the beach instead of my place, gather shells and you'll build him a sandcastle.
I don't need some Gideon to tell me where your family.
I knew that long ago.
I just need you to know you have something to return to, that I haven't given up, that you live in my dreams, asking me to trust in you,
asking for a little more, and I trust you completely, giving you that little more.
With all the love in my heart and with a tiny baby who already knows how to say, come, come down.
